user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (char *str,
                                      bool *broken_encoding)
{
#ifdef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  size_t len;
  size_t res;

  len = strlen (str);
  res = MHD_str_pct_decode_lenient_n_ (str, len, str, len, broken_encoding);
  str[res] = 0;

  return res;
#else  /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
  size_t r;
  size_t w;
  if (NULL != broken_encoding)
    *broken_encoding = false;
  r = 0;
  w = 0;
  while (0 != str[r])
  {
    const char chr = str[r++];
    if ('%' == chr)
    {
      const char d1 = str[r++];
      if (0 == d1)
      {
        if (NULL != broken_encoding)
          *broken_encoding = true;
        str[w++] = chr; /* Copy "as is" */
        str[w] = 0;
        return w;
      }
      else
      {
        const char d2 = str[r++];
        if (0 == d2)
        {
          if (NULL != broken_encoding)
            *broken_encoding = true;
          str[w++] = chr; /* Copy "as is" */
          str[w++] = d1; /* Copy "as is" */
          str[w] = 0;
          return w;
        }
        else
        {
          const int h = toxdigitvalue (d1);
          const int l = toxdigitvalue (d2);
          unsigned char out;
          if ((0 > h) || (0 > l))
          {
            if (NULL != broken_encoding)
              *broken_encoding = true;
            str[w++] = chr; /* Copy "as is" */
            str[w++] = d1;
            str[w++] = d2;
            continue;
          }
          out =
            (unsigned char) (((uint8_t) (((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) h)) << 4))
                             | ((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l)));
          str[w++] = (char) out;
          continue;
        }
      }
    }
    str[w++] = chr;
  }
  str[w] = 0;
  return w;
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no use of compiler language extensions in the provided function. Specifically:
- No use of compiler-specific keywords or constructs such as __attribute__, __asm__, __inline__ (compiler-prefixed), typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as expressions, nested functions, or other recognized GCC/clang/MSVC extensions.
- No use of compiler built-ins or intrinsic functions (e.g. __builtin_*, _Interlocked*, etc.).
- Only standard types and headers appear to be implied/used (size_t, uint8_t, unsigned char, int, char, bool) which are part of standard C (C99 and later for bool/stdint). Their usage here does not rely on an extension.
- Preprocessor conditional (#ifdef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE) is standard preprocessor usage and not a language extension.
- All casts and pointer/array operations use standard C syntax.
- No inline assembly, extended inline asm constraints, or nonstandard pragmas are present.

Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions). If you want, I can re-scan for other categories of potential MISRA violations (naming, implicit conversions, null pointer checks, bounds, etc.).
